communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: The imports of coal from January 1 to August 2 amounted to 677,455 tons, as compared to 555,235 tons during the same period last year.

div.p: During the Hamzaoui fire the library of the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate, which contains a number of precious M88. was served, thanks to the courage and presence of mind displayed by the priests.

div.head: Abou el Ala al Husseini Mouled.
div.p: The Mouled ot Aboa el Ala el Hasseini was held on Thursday evening at Boulaye, Cairo. The mosque and the neighboring houses were illuminated. The ceremony was attended by a large number of patives.

div.head: Is it?
div.p: The best means of winning the regard of Egyptians and weaning their leaders from their reliance on Turkey, is to convince them that their aspirations for a more equal law and a faller measure of self-government are sure of a sympathetic consideration in England. ("Tribune.")

div.head: Retirement of P. and O. General Manager.
div.p: The "Shipping Gazette" understands that Mr. F. R. Kendall is shortly retiring from the post of chief general manager of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company. Mr. Kendall, who succeeded the late Mr. F.D. Barnes, recently completed his 50th year in the company's service.

div.head: Victim to Devotion.
div.p: At Eanch the other day, a Dervish was found dead in the mosque, with a wound on his breast. The unhappy man belonged to the sect who, like the Persian zealote, slashes themselves with knives. He had evidently been - practicing his peculiar devotion but had struck too hard

div.head: Alhambra Theater.
div.p: This evening, Sig. Novelli's company will give Trojabi's comedy Venti Minuti di Fer. mata, preceded by the one-set comedy Cavalle riza. Two performances will be given tomorrow, Padrone delle Ferriere ("The Ironmaster") in the afternoon, and D'Annunzio's tragedy Gioconda in the evening.

div.head: Praise of the Administration.
div.p: A khattab was lately inaugurated at Talrak. near Zagazig, under the presidency of the Sheikh El Ansari, inspector of schools in the Sbarkieh, who made a speech in which, after enumerating the benefits of the present Government, compared it with the arbitrary Government of former times,and wound up with an allusion to Lord Cromer as the "Reformer of Egypt."

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN QUESTION.
div.p: GERMAN COOPERATION.

div.head: MEETING OF KING AND KAISER.
div.p: (Gazette’s Special Service. )

Berlin, Saturday, August 4. The Dentache Revue," in an article on Anglo-German relations, says that the approaching meeting of King Edward and the Emperor William should pave the way to a better understanding between England and Germany. It is probable that Great Britain will ask for German assent to Lord Cromer's programme for the abolition of the extra-territorial rights of foreigners resident in Egypt, and also for the co-operation of European diplomacy in certain questions connected with Egypt. It suggests that Germany should obtain some concession to enable her to realize her cherished desire for a terminus in the Persian Gulf for the Baghdad Railway.

div.head:
THE EGYPTIAN PRESS.
MR. FINDLAY'S CHARGES.
div.p: The passage in the recent White Book on the Denishwai affair which will arouse the greatest local interest in Egypt is contained in the telegram sent from Alexandria on July 5th from Mr. Findlay to Sir Edward Grey. Therein the British Chargé d'Affaires brings most serious charges against that portion of the European and native Press which indulged in a campaigned against the action that was taken by the Egyptian Government at that time. Mr. Findlay, in his telegram to the Foreign Secretary, explicitly states that bribes must have been given to the European and native Press in order to conduct the campaign. He remarks: -

"The local press campaign, in which both European and native journals are engaged, has recommenced with such violence and is being conducted with such an absolute disregard for truth as to make it evident that large sums of money have been expended."

This charge of wholesale bribery of the local Press would not have been made by such a high British official to Sir Edward Grey unless he had had, we presume, ample grounds for coming to such a conclusion. The serious nature of the accusation is obvious for it embraces European and native newspapers as well. It will be interesting to observe if our contemporaries, who are involved in this accusation, will take any measures in order to endeavor to refute these charges against their integrity.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: A Council of Ministers was held yesterday at San Stefano, when the following were approved :

1. A law applying to foreigners the provisions of Art. 338 of the Native Penal Code, punishing various offanoes connected with public morals, and in particular those relating to solicitation in the streets.
2. A law instituting & Mixed Local Commission at Beni Souef.

div.head: EDUCATION DEPARTMENT.
div.p: The Ministry of Public Instruction has named Sheikh Mohamed Hassanein El Amrawi to be professor of Arabic at Oxford in succession to Sheikh Jaouich, whose contract has expired, and who has been appointed inspector of English primary schools. The Ministry has decided to send Mohamed El Hussein, professor of English at the Mohamed Ali School, and Mobsmed Kamel, professor at the school of Mansourah, to complete their studies in a normal school in England.

div.head: GREAT BRITAIN IN EGYPT.
div.p: SIR RUDOLPH SLATIN'S VIEWS.

In an interview published in the "Neue Freie Press" (Vienna), Sir Rodolph Slatin Pasha made an interesting statement on the present situation in Egypt. He said: -- "The censure passed by the European Press on the punishment of the offenders was not justified, for only drastic measures avail in such cases, and only by severity and fear can a frenzied people be brought to reason. "I do not believe serious danger is imminent, but to obviate any such peril in the future, it must be shown that as Great Britain has not only the will but also the power to maintain her position in Egypt. The garrisons must be increased, and the Egyptians must learn that behind every indi- individual englishman stand hundreds ready to avenge any outbreak. As regards the condition of the Egyptian army, there is not the slightest ground for. doubting the loyalty of the officers and men. In conclusion, Siri Rudolph warned those circles in Barope which are continually agitating against Great Britain that an outbreak of religious fanaticism among to Mohamedans would not only injure British ti role in the East, but that other States having the political and economic interests there would suffer also
Commenting on the above, the "Globe" says :

When two such pre-eminent authorities on Egyptian affairs as Lord Cromer and Satin Pasha are in complete agreement, a very heavy weight of refutation must be supplied to ever shake their joint pronouncement They are at one in affirming the urgenta necessity of substantially strengthening the te British garrison on the Nile; "the Egyptians th must learn," Sir Radolph now declares, "that behind every individual Edglishman stand o | hundreds ready to avenge any on the break." And what would be the best, indeed, the only method of impressing that fact on the Turkish and other foreign propagandists of militant Pan-Islamism? More regiments of British soldiers should be immediately placed in evidence; those already in garrison are too few to create the required impression of irresistible strength. That is the situation as described by the two statesmen whose knowledge of Egypt, both Lower and Upper, goes down to the very roots of every outstanding problem. But Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman and his colleagues actually presume to imagine that they know far better than those who have passed the greater portion of their active lives on the Nile. Instead of at onset reinforcing the British occupying force, they have decreed its weakening by diminishing its reserves at Malta and Gibraltar. Mr. Haldane's scheme of so-called reorganization permanently withdraws two battalions from the former fortress and one from the latter, but these troops, instead of being dispatched to Egypt, are marked out for almost immediate disbandment. The extraordinary conceit of the Cabinet in floating such men as Lord Cromer and Sir Rudolph Slatin is not less amazing than it is disgraceful. Ministers would, apparently, relish the severance of all ties binding the two countries together.

div.head: THE BRITISH GARRISON.
div.p: FORTHCOMING MOVES.

An order published in General Orders yesterday confirms the moves in connection with the British garrison in Egypt which we have already announced. The lat Battalion King's Own Scottish Borderers and the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards will come out from home to Egypt, and the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment and 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers will leave the country, the former for India and the latter for Malta.

The Colonel Commanding desires to express his high appreciation of the manner in which the trooping of the Colour was carried out by the 1st Bo. Lancashira Fusiliers, on the left inst., the Anniversary of the Battle of Minden. The steadiness on parade and the smartness of the tarn-out reflected the greatest credit on all concerned.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: DISCUSSED BY IMPERIAL DEFENSE COMMITTEE

The Prime Minister last Thursday presided over a meeting of the Committee of Imperial Defence held at the offices in Whitehall Gardens. The attendance included Sir Elward Grey, Mr. John Morley, Lord Twsedmoath. Mr. Haldane, Viscount Esher, General Grierson, General tha Hon. Sir N. Lyttelton, Captain Ottley, R. N., the Secretary and the Assistant Secretary. It is understood that the military aspect of the situation in Egypt was under review, and that advantage was taken of the presence of the Earl of Cromer in London to hear from him in person his views on the subject. Major-General Sir Reginald Wingate, the Sirdar, was also brought into consultation.

div.head: GREEK ORTHODOXY IN EGYPT.
div.p: OPPOSITION TO LORD CROMER.
THE STATUS OF THE PATRIARCHATE.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,--If opposition there is to the scheme of Lord Cromer for abolishing the Capitulations, that opposition will come-and it will be of the most determined kind - from the Greek Or thodox community subject to the ecolesiasical authority of the Greek Patriarch of Alexandria, as distinguished from the Hellenio colony, ander the role of the Hellenic Consulate General and Diplomatic Agency.

Phat opposition, the reasons for which were justified the other day by a high dignitary of the Orthodox Greek Chareb, with whom the writer had a conversation, rests upon thoroughly legal ground, confirmed by political tradition, that of the suzerainty of the Sultan in Egypt, which in the case.of the Orthodox holds as good to-day as it did in the days of Ismail Pasha. When the time comes for introducing the new order of things, the abolition of the Capitulations, it is this question of the status and jurisdiction of the Greek Patriarchate, the most influential in the East, which will form probably the most vexed to deal with, and for the following reasons :

The Greek Patriarch of Alexandris is subject directly to the Sublime Ottoman Porte, which ratifies the election to the Patriarchal Throne by the issue of a Beirat of Investiture, as in the case of the succession of a Khedive.

Once the bulwark of the Capitulations is demolished, it will be a moot point to determine what will be the political status of the Patriarchate. Will it remain under Ottoman jurisdiction, or revert to Egyptian law ? Or will international adjustment be made by the Powers in virtue of which the Orthodox Greek community will enjoy the protection of the Kingdom of Hellas ?

In any event, and granted that the abolition takes place, whatever the advantages or disadvantages of that change, the Greek Patriarchate--in common with that of the Maronites, the Armenians, Gregorians - is inevitably bound to lose by the transaction both in authority and immemorial prestige ; for the mass of those Rehabs subject to its Canons will either, as Ottoman subjects, find themselves subject regarding their civil affairs to Egyptian control - control to which instinctively they have immense objection or they will possibly petition the Powers-to the detriment of the Patriarchate-to secede to the authority of the Hellenic Consulate General; and this latter alternative is most | likely, as already it is adopted by the majority of Greek Ottoman subjects arriving in Egypt.

The number of Rsyahs, however, is considerable, and they are subject as regards all civil matters to the Patriarchal Court, which decides suits for divorce, the probate of wills, and all other matters wherein the Patriarchal seal is necessary. The fate of this jurisdiction, with its municipal and other privileges, granted unto the Orthodox Greek: by Mshomed II., will be interesting. For the sake of history, any alteration or detriment to the Court wherein the Code of Justinian is adhered to with strict regard to the form as it was fashioned by the greatest lawgiver of the Christian Era, is much to be regretted. For the Patriarchate, it means much more than the severance with tradition.

I understand that the Patriarch desires to undertake a journey to Tripoli, partly for reasons of health, partly to visit the Greek Churches at Tripoli, Benghazi, Sfax, and Tanis, but there is some difficulty about securing permission for him to do so. Hie Bestitude must procare an Irade from HI.M. the Sultan.
DR. VERVEROPOULO'S MURDER.

Yesterday afternoon, a post-mortem examination was held at the Greek Hospital on the body of Dr. Ververopoulos whose tragic death we report yesterday. Officials from the Hellenic and Italian Consulates were present. The murdered man was buried after the examination had concluded.

div.head:
ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS.
LATEST ADDITIONS TO MENAGERIE.
div.p: During the months of June and July numerous interesting additions have been made to the menagerie in the Ghizeh Gardens. Among these the» most valuable are a ball and a cow, & very five young pair, of that remarkable animal, the white-tailed gnu, or black wildebeest, once so numerous on the plains of South Africa but now so rare that even young specimens sell in Barope for from £70 to £100 each.

In the edition of Cavier's "Animal Kingdom" published in London in 1810 we find the Antilops gnu thus described :-"A very extraordinary species, which, at first sight, seems to be a monstrous being, compounded of parts of different animals. It has the body and crapper of a small horse, covered with brown hair ; the tail furnished with long white hairs, like that of a horse ; and on the neck & beautiful flowing mane, white at base, and black at the tips of the hairs. Its borns, approximated and enlarged at the base, like those of the Cape buffalo, descend outwardly, and torn ap at the point; the muzzle. is large, flat, and surrounded by a circle of projecting hairs ; under the throat and dewlap is another black mane; and the legs are as slender and light as those of a stag. Both sexes have horns."

In the days before this animal had become Nearly extinct, it was hunted for commercial purposes (and the indiscriminate manner in which it seems to have been killed off by the old-time South African bonters may account for its present rarity). The hide produced a strong leather, the long and silky white tails sold at a high price as "chowries” or fly-switches, and the horns were of value for carving into knife handles and other articles ; the flesh was also eaten, resembling coarse beef.
Interesting Arrivals.

Other interesting arrivals at the Ghizeh Zoological Gardens include:-a Syrian hyrax, the "Coney" of the Scripture”, from the Peninsula of Sinai, presented by Miralai R. C. R. Owen Bey, E. A, on the 3rd of Jane; seven Caspian terrapins, from the Beirut River, presented by Prof. A. B. Day, of the Syrian Protestant College, Beyroat; 4th June, three gray-headed love birds, from Madagascar, presented by Mrs. Perry, 7th Jone; ten Austrian snakes presented by Dr. Franz Werner, of Veins, 13:h June; one Grivet monkey presented by Mr. F. Eagene Mason ; one black lemur and one ring-tailed lemur, presented by the Hon. Charles J. Littleton on 21st Jane ; a Grivet monkey presented by Mme Vve Beligman Bey on the 28th Jane! a young wolf from Mount Lebanon, presented by Prof. A. E. Day, 29th Jane; a Cyprian hare presented by Mr. R. L. N. Miobell, H, M. Commissioner, Limassol, 2nd July;s collection of small but rare fish and some water plants, presented by Mr. C. H. Schoeller, of Alexandria, 7th July; and an Æthio pian hedgehog, presented by Mr. Noel Griffin, 11th July; one Grivet monkey, presented by Mr. Graham C. Karr, of Saakio, 15th July ; a sociable vulture, from Esneh, presented by Mr. A. Rosenzweig, 24th July,
Born in the Gardens.

An Ariel Gazella soemmerringi was born in the gardens on the 26th of July, and among additions by purchase and exchange attention may be specially called to the following:three young drills, a species of West African baboon which grows to an immense size and which has not previously been exhibited at Ghizeh ; one tayra, carnivorous American animal in appearance something midway between an otter and a weasel (the tayra has- & bad reputation; in Natural History books one finds it that's described : "ugly and forbidding, malignant and bloodthirsty beyond any. thing in nature," etc.; however, the specimen at Ghizeh does not liva ap to this character, but is a cheerful and playful baast with a hand some cost of red browa far and a bushy tail); a kinkajou, or American potto; three individuals of the Cape hyrax, called "Dassie" in parts of South Africa, and also known under the names of Daman and Klippschliefer; a pair of os basaar, or nakai tailed armadillos, are a novelty in Egypt; and finally should be mentioned a richly marked python, about ten feet long, from West Africa, which arrived on the 9th of July.

The Zoological Gardens at Ghizeh, Cairo, are open daily from 9am till sunset. The admission on week-days : P.T. $ each person, and on Sundays P.T. 5 each person. There are band performances on Sundays and Fridays from €-6 p.m.

div.head: DEFENCE OF THE SUEZ CANAL
div.p: The following appears in Parisian newspaper from a Berlin correspondent :

"Ce n'est pas sans un certain étonnement que dans les milieux politiques allemands on a appris que le gouvernement anglo-égyptien, sur la demande de lord Cromer, se propose de procéder à la défense du Canal de Suez. Oa croit que c'est un défi lancé aux puissances et une rupture de la neutralité internationale. Le prétexte invoqué pour la mise en état de de. feng da canal est une "incursion tentée dans le but de provoquer une explosion de fanatisme en Egypte." Le présence de la Turquie sur un point quelconque de la rive Asie da canal aurait provoqué cette mesure de toute gravité."
POUR TOUS LES AGES.

Le meilleur des systèmes est celui qui peut s'assouplir à tous les âges ; ainsi en est-il du système Berlitz, 8938i pratique pour les enfants que pour les grandes personnes et aussi fécond en beureux résultats. Au Caire (No 1, Rae Kemal) comme à Alexandrie (19, Rae Rosette) les élèves de tous les âges prodigaent par l'ananimité de leur satisfaction, la plus belle et le plus sincère louange au système Berlitz.

div.head: RUSSIAN CRISIS.
div.p: THE KRONSTADT MUTINY.
ADMIRAL KILLED.
ST. PETERSBURG, August 3.

The mutineers at Kronstadt were composed of 400 sappers and miners and 2,500 sailors. The former killed their officers and then surprised the sleeping artillerymen of Fort Con- stantine, capturing the officers. The gunners, however, proved to be unexpectedly loyal and refused to work the guns, thus making resistance hopeless, especially as the authorities. were fully prepared and were backed up by an overwhelming force of reliable troops. Seven of the miners were tried by court-martial for killing their officers and were immediately shot. The cause of the outbreak is purely political. Revolutionaries were most active but were disappointed by the loyalty shown by the infantry and artillerymen, although the latter were the first to revolt last October.
A military outbreak has taken place at Reval. No details have come to hand. (Reuter
ST. PETERSBURG, August 2.

Matineers on board the cruiser, Pamiat Azo- va, of the Baltic Squadron, killed the com- mander and four officers, but were overpowered by the loyal members of the crew and brought into Reval, where they were disarmed and imprisoned.

The officers who were attacked by the mutineers at Kronstadt showed splendid courage. All of them who were killed or wounded fell fighting. The killed include Rear Admiral Bleckemisheff and Captain Rodnieff. The latter fought in the battle of Taushima. (R.)
ST. PETERSBURG August 3.
Admiral Beckemisheff was killed during the troubles at Kronstadt.
A general strike has commenced hara. (H.)

div.head: LATEST TURKISH INTRIGUE.
div.p: FRANCE AND DJANET.
PARIS, August 3.
France has presented a strong protest to Turkey, against her occupation of the oneis of Djanet, in the hinterland of Tripoli.
The Porte, in reply, maintains her claim to regard Djanet as an integral portion of Tripoli.
(Reuter)
PARIS, August 3.
The Porte disputes France's claim to the Oasis of Djanet, claiming it as an integral por-
tion of the vilayet of Tripoli.
(Havas)

div.head: FIRE AT MILAN EXHIBITION.
div.p: TWO ART SECTIONS DESTROYED.
MILAN, August 3.
A disastrous fire broke out in the Exhibition. The Italian and Hungarian art sections have been destroyed. The other sections are intact. The damage is estimated at £160,000.
(Reuter,

div.head: CHINESE CUSTOMS.
div.p: STATEMENT BY SIR E. GREY.
LONDON, August 3.

HOUSE OF COMMONS-Sir E. Grey stated that the new instructions given to Sir Robert Hart do not appear contrary to the assurance given by the Chinese Government that the actual administration of the Customs would continue unchanged, but "I am inquiring," he said, "whether this was made quite clear by the Government." There is no reason to believe the report of Sir Robert Hart's intended resignation. (Router)

div.head: DEATH OF SIR S. WATERLOW.
div.p: LONDON, August 3.
Sir Sydney Waterlow, K.C.V.O., is dead.
(Peuter)

The late Sir Sydney Hedley Waterlow, Bart., K.C.V.O., was once Lord Mayor of London, in 1872 73, during which the Shah of Persia visited the City. He was elected to Parliament several times. From 1868-69 he sat as member for the County of Dumfries, from 1874-80 he represented Maidstone, and Gravesend from 1880-85. The late Sir Sidney took the great- est interest in public institutions. In fact most of his time was occupied of late years in the performance of his duties as chairman of the Distribution Committee of the Hospital Sun- day Fund; chairman of the General Commissioners of Income Tax in the City of London.; chairman of the Industrial Dwellings Co., with 6000 tenements and 30,000 souls; and chair- man of the Board of Governors of the United Westminster Schools, educating 1.100 boya- all of this work being nearly honorary. A few years ago he gave over to the LC.C. his estate at Highgate-about 30 acres and this is now known as Waterlow Park.
PIERRE LOTI.
PARIS, August 3.
Pierre Loti has been appointed a naval captain. (Havos)

div.head: HOW TO INCREASE THE POPULATION.
div.p: The Mayor of Montirat, in the Tarn, which both geographically and psychologically be- longs to the Midi, has been dismissed by the Home Office for overzealousness in the cause of re-population. His zeal was only on paper, it is true, but he did his best, and he evidently meant for the best. When the last census papers came in, he thought he would not trouble the inhabitants of Montirat with them, and filled every one ap himself, duly signing each householder's name. While busy at this self-imposed task he reflected that France is threatened with depopulation. Thereupon he began adding to each family a boy here and a girl there, and occasionally a pair of twins. By the time he had done so, the population of Montirat had increased by about 100 souls. It was only on paper, but it was better than nothing. The Government has refrained from prosecuting the mayor with a southern imagination for forgery, and has merely taken his office from him.

div.head: TWO OPERATIONS FOR KIDNEY DISEASE.
div.p: Pain and Weakness in the Back;
Dizzy Spells; Poor Appetite;
Urinary Disorders, etc.
Patient suffered 30 Years, and
28 Doctors took up the Case.

Maxwell Place, Uddingston, Glasgow, Scotland. For thirty years I was a martyr to what I always believed was kidney disease. The first sign, I can well remember, was a dull pain and weakness in my back, followed by headaches and dizzy spells. My body and limbs swelled, and my eyesight was affected. I lost my appetite, and my tongue used to be thickly coated. (I ought also to tell you, as further proof of my trouble being with the kidneys, that the urine was very thick and un-
natural.)

During those thirty years of suffering, I tried doctor after doctor, without getting any better. Altogether twenty-eight doctors took up my case, but all alike seemed unable to help me. Twice I was obliged to undergo agonizing operations, and these failed to relieve me, the doctors declared I could never be cured.

I had spent nearly all my savings on doc- tors' fees and medicines, when, about four months ago, I came to hear of Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. I began with these, and before many days had passed I could tell they were doing me good; my back was certainly a little easier, and sleep at nights was more refreshing. I continued with the medicine, and it is one of the greatest pleasures in my life to be able to tell you that they have made me quite a different woman. I feel better now than I have been for the past thirty years. My appetite is wonderfully im- proved, and I do not suffer like I used to from backache and headache. My eyesight is better, and 1 am not troubled with the dizzy spells; the urine is clear and natural.

I gladly give you permission to publish this, and I hope it will be helpful to others. Yours gratefully, (Signed) Mrs. E. MILLS. Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 18 P.T. per box; or 71 P.T. for 6 boxes; or they may have been direct from the general agent for Egypt,- Max Fischer, Mousky Street, Cairo.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
div.p: EXTRACTS FROM THE HOME PAPERS.
The Education Bill Farce.

p.hi: If anybody hoped that much would be achieved by the Opposition, strenuously backed as they often wire by the Irish Party, and by frank utterances from other quarters of the House, they have been cruelly disappointed The Kincation Bill will leave the House of Commas with all substantial grieve completely unredressed. The only modifications made by the Government have been, oddly enough, in derogation from their own great principles. What has become of the uniform type of school under complete popular con- trol

div.p: The Government arrested three types in the Bill itself, and not content with that, they have actually created a fourth-the State aided school-in their amendments to Clause 4. We always granted that a strong case might be made out for unification, and was supposed that to be the position of the Government themselves. The result they have arrived at shows the Nemesis lying in wait for anybody who tries to impose one single type of teaching, and is driven by stress of circumstances to "graft exceptions on exceptions." "Timer.")
Shifting the Responsibility.

It must be borne in mind that in establishing responsible Government in the two new Colonies (in South Africa) which five years ago were hostile states, the British Government are making an entirely novel precedent. la every other c) soo) a gift has been made in response to the request of a loyal and practically unanimous community. It has been the reward of a novitiate spent in long training for liberty. In this instance we are conferring an unsought privilege- one which is reputed by the very men to whom in the last resort we must look for active help and assistance. Were they inclined to stand upon their fall right, and refuse to participate in the undesired institutions, thy could, beyond all doubt, condemn this adventurous experiment to a public failure. It is only because Ministers rely on the 60 operation unwilling though it be, of the British settlers that they dare to dream of enfranchising the Boers. ("Standard.")
Unenviable Greatness.

The new Prime Minister of the Russian Empire, M. Sto'ypin, has before him a stipend ous task, but he has at least the prospect of living history as the greatest of Russian statesmen should be be so fortunate as to carry it through to a successful end. Assuming that he means what he says, and that he is not the mere tool of reaction, he will have with him the good wishes of the well-disposed in all nations, and it possible that the consciousness of sympathy so universal may help to inspire him in the discharge of his C onerous duty. ("Globe.")
Peace, or a Sword?

The Russians are apparently of a much less excitable temperament, much less mobile, than the Prenoh. The dissolution of the Dams has been received quietly, but there is no evidence that this quietness means indifference. The new Government declares that its pro- gramme or late government, coupled with reform. That is the sort of compromise which i C shows that even on the barrauratio side no one any longer, believes in the possibility, of mere repression. Ite weak point is that the people will construe reform as an admission li that the reformers are right, and will take oppression as proot that the Government is wrong.. The whole issue thorns on the demand for Representative Government. The struggle will go on until Representative Government has been established. But how long it t will last cannot be foreseen. It may be for five years and it may be for fifty. ("Morning Post.")" .
Ideal, but Unsafe

"When members of the British or French Parliaments take an engagement to work for d the reduction of armaments and to create a movement of public opinion in that direction T their promises are not vain, because in both countries Parliament really holds sovereign power, but when, on the contrary, the same engagement is taken by members of the Reichst tag what is it worth? In France the Chamber does what it wills In Germany it does whilst the Emperor wille, or, more exactly. the Emperor does what will be wil's, whether Parliament likes it or not. What, then, do they signify, the pacifist jeu de paume oaths, when some of those f who make them bring the reality of power and responsibility, and others only fistions! Our pacifists will keep their word and begin their propaganda, and when some fine morning, as daring the Morocco business, they will find that their foreign colleagues have lagged behind, and that we are playing the game of military enfeeblement alone. Grand merci! Doubtless Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman has not thought of all that. He has abandoned himself to the inspirations of his own kind and honest spirit. As a man he was in the right, as a Prime Minister he was in the wrong. For the Golden Age is not yet come." ("Tempe.")
Germany Unconcerned.

The Prime Minister's open championship of the disgraced Dams can hardly be reconciled with the efforts of those who are aiming at a rapprochement between England and the Russian Government (sic). But that, of course, is a matter about which Germans need not worry themselves. ("Prankfurter Zaitung.") .
Immortal Suffragettes The most valuable of the recent acquisitions in the National Gallery is the famous undraped suffragette, known as "Venus and Copi4," by Velasquith. (Panch.")

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers Battevant, has received orders to supply" draft of 10) non commissioned officers and men to join the 1st Battalion, at Alexandria, early in October. The draft will leave on the Tat October, and Second Lieutenant J. M. Mood, 1st Royal Dablin Fosiliers, has been placed on duty with it.
The 3rd Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, Aldershot, is preparing a draft of 100 non- commissioned officers and men to join the 1st Battalion at Cairo, early in October.
A draft of 50 men, of the Reserve Squadron of the Inniskilling Dragoons, Ballicollig, will leave there on the 1st October to join the regiment at Cairo.
The 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, which went last year from Egypt to Chambattia, will remain at that station for another year.
The Rifle Depot, and the King's Royal Rifle Corps and the Rifle Brigade wil not be tampered with under Mr. Haldane's proposed reforms.""

The vacancy for squadron commander in the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, Cairo, has been filled by the promotion to substantive rank of Brevet Major G K. Ansell, the noted polo player. Major Ansell has been connected with the Inniskillings for over twelve years, having got his first commission in April, 1894. He was promoted esptain in 1901, and was adjutant of the regiment 1897-1902, which embraced the South African War. Since February, 1905, he has been employed as Brigade Major of the 3rd Cavalry Brigade, Carragh. Major Ansell served with the Inniskillings in the operations in the Transvaal, east of Pretoria, including the actions of Rietvlei and Belfast; the operations in Cape Colony, south of Orange River, in- leading the fighting about Colesberg; and the operations generally in the Transvaal and Orange River Colony, till the close of the war. He had many exciting adventures during the Boer War. His love for scouting alone got him into a tight corner on one occasion, and the treachery of a supposed loyalist led the gallant subaltern to make a three months' sojourn in Pretoria, where he remained till it was captured. At the action of Grootvlei, where the Inniskillings got in a charge, Captain Ansell, armed with a bayonet, had a band-to-band encounter with a Boer, both mounted, and after an exciting tussle, during which the Boer fired twice, he got the upper hand of the Boer and took him prisoner. In the drives, Captain Anrell was Rimington's right-hand man, and his well-merited brevet majority was his reward, in addition to the Queen's medal with these clasps, and King's medal with two clasps

The home batteries and companies of the Royal Horse Artillery, Royal Field Artillery, and Royal Garrison Artillery are preparing strong drafts for the batteries and companies in India. These will be dispatched early in October. When the wants of India, Egyptrand the Colonies are supplied Mr. Haldane will have little or no difficulty in fixing the establishment, so far as the personnel is concerned, of his alleged four-gun and two-gun batteries.

The Bank of England authorities have no official knowledge as yet that the Guards are to be relieved of night duty at that institution. If, however, the rumor proves correct, it will mean the severance of a long standing tie, whose aspects are piquant as well as historical. Ever since the Gordon riots, in 1780, when old inkstands were melted into bullets in defense of the Bank, it has been customary to set a military watch over the O'd Lady of Threadneedle street at night, and to this duty the Guards have tenaciously alleged. It is said that the broods over the Tower were the first cause of this attachment. From it the lucky subaltern found glorious escape at the Bank of England, where, we are told, there was always provided a "anog, plain, ex- cellent dinner," brought from one of the beit taverns in the neighborhood. Moreover, the officer had the privilege of inviting two friends, for whom, as for himself, the ample provision was made in the matter of wire. As for the guard, they always got extra pay-all except the bugler, who was dependent on contributions from the sergeants-ro that night duty at the Bank was always welcomed.

On occasion the Gourds have banded over the Tower to the care of some regiment of the line, and they then parted willingly with every obligation except that of providing the "inlying picquet" at the Bank. To that they resolutely adhered. The consequence has been that for many years past the sight has often been witnessed of Guards from the barracks in the far West-end "gaily charging home to the Bank of England." It was not, it is said, the balloon in the taults, nor the miles of City maids or dew-these last long since departed to the suburbs--which helped the subaltern of an earlier period to endure the weary march City wards. "It was," ssyr an old-time writer, "be substantial, savonry fare of the City genuine roast beef of Old England, and the City's ancient port-far surpassing the French cookery and the French wine of St. James's."

div.head: JUVENILE SMOKING.
div.p: We lately published a paragraph on this subject, which is being dealt with by the House of Lords, and, we hope, with success. The evil is not, unhappily, confined to Britain. Nearly every European boy under 16 smokes "on the quiet"; and in the East it seems to be quite the fashion for youngsters who may not have out their second teeth to indulge in the habit openly, without let or hindrance. Surely this must be very bad for the health, especially the eyesight, and one cannot wonder at the number of cases of ophthalmic which are to be met with in the East, Egypt, and elsewhere. The foolish indulgence of Oriental parents is not only extended to cigarettes In Greek and Levantine Christian homes it is not at all thought wrong to give a child wine or spirits, and to allow it to eat a heavy supper and keep late hours; in fact do just as its elders do. The good old nursery rules and diet are lacking in the Bastern household; a nursery does not exist, and the result is that by eating and drinking and sitting up with adults the child becomes precocious, sickly, unfit for the manly exercise of limb and brain. We sincerely trust that the Juvenile Smoking Prevention Act will have far-reaching effects in the domestic politics of the world.

Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
Le Caire, 3 Août 1906.

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais est resté, hier, invarié à 87 3/4. L'Unifiée a baisé de 1/4 de livre à 104 1/4. La National Bank est remontée de 1/4 à 25 1/2. L'Agricole est de meurés inchangée à 9 5/8, de même que la Daira à 16 7/8. La Delta Light a gag: é 1/4 à 11 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Ezyptien est renseignée en baisse de 3 francs à 757. La Banque d'Athènes est restée stationnaire à

Nous avons eu, ce matin, un marobé indé- cis et platos faible, mais assez mouvementé. Comme hier, les transactions ont porté princi- palement sur les Delta Land, qu'on a fait descndre jusqu'aux abords de £ 31/16.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a débuté à 25 7/16 pour c'ôturer à 25 3/8-7/16. L'Agricole a faibli à 95,8. Le Comptoir Financier a réactionné à 6 3/8-7/16 l'action ancienne, et 6 3/16-1/4 la nouvelle.

Le Crédit Foncier, sans affaires, a été coté 757. La Daira a faibli à 16 13/16-7/8 et le Wardan Estate & 6 5/8 3/4. La Nile Land s'est raffermie à 13-13 1/16. L'action Agricole du Nil a reculé à 270; par contre la part de fondateurs progressé à 7 1/16.Les Improvements Corporation ont avancé à 4 11/16-34. L'action Batreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été demandée à 4 3/32. La part de fondateur Allot- ment s'est inscrite à 192 3.

LHeliopolis se sont maintenus entre 287 et 288. La Brasserie des Pyramides a passé de 128 à 181. Les dividendes Tramways d'Alex- andrie ont perda 2 francs à S.S. Les Auto- mobiles ont gagné 1/16 4 13/16.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont été traités à 16, les Egyptian à 5 13/16-7/8 et les Uppe: Egypt à 4 3/4-13/16 Parmi les petitas valeurs, les Delta Land ont alôturé à 3 1/16-1/8. Les Estates ont été échangés à 1 3/4-13/16. Les Constructions ont faibli à 1 7/16-1/2. Les Oasis ont été démandés 18/32 et les Cotton Mills à 5 sh. 9. La Khedivial Mail est revenue à 32 sb. 6. Les Sucreries ont avancé à 25-26 francs.

Les actionnaires de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. sont convoqués en assem- blée générale ordinaire pour le 16 Août oog- rant, au siège social à Londres. A l'ordre da jour: rapport du Conseil d'administration, comptes et bilan pour le semestre finissant le 31 Mars 1906, et confirmation, s'il y a lien, des résolutions prises à l'assemblée extraordi naire du 19 Juillet dernier.
Il ressort principalement du rapport des ad- ministrateurs qui sera la à l'assemblée du 16 Août que:

1. A la clôture de l'état arrêté le 30 Sep- tembre 1905, la superficie des terrains achetés par la Compagnie comprenait environ 479, 275 feldans, ayant e Q'é £127,950, sans compter une participation d'un sixième dans d'excellen- tas propriétés aoqaises dans la Gharbieh, d'a. e étendue de 1,577 feddans.

Les principales possessions de la Compagnie sont dans le voisinage da Caira, Tantah, Benhs et autres importantes villes et villages. Dapais lors, c'est-à-dire pendant le semestre dont il est renda compte, il a é'é encore ache té 30,178 feddans pour £4 320. La Compagnie a eu, en outre, des participations dans d'autres acquisitions dont le coût a été de £ 164, 02. Bref, le montant total des achats faits par la Compagnie an 3 mars 1905 s'élevait à £ 305,990, sur lequel il resterait à payer £104,695. Le bilan établit les prix d'achat.

Le développement et l'amélioration de oes propriétés ont été particul'èrement soigné- et ont donné les résultats les plas satisfaisants. Les premières ventes (Meadi) ont été rés lisées après la clôture des comptes de ce semestre, et leurs résultats ne sauraient figurer que dans l'exposé du smestre suivant.

3. Les administrateurs annoncent que le ventes de terrains seront reprises vers la fin de cette année, pendant la saison des affaires, et que ces ventes promettent de donner des béné fces considérables.
Comme on le voit, cet exposé ne justifie pas précisément les appréciations dont il a été l'ob- jet "a priori" dans le camp des bsissiers.

Le marché des valears étant fermé les sa medis pendant la saison d'été, et la Bourse devant, probablement, rester close lundi pro- chain (Bank Holiday à Londres) le prochain numéro de notre Circulaire paraitra le mardi 7 Août courant, ou bien le lundi 6, si le marché get ouvert.
